title: Brazilian Organic Honey from Atlantic Rainforest Decreases Inflammatory Process in Mice
abstract: Honey is an ancient food in the human diet, and the chemical composition of some types of honey has been associated with several beneficial biological effects. Among them, honey has been highlighted to improve health and control inflammatory processes. However, there is no study elucidating the mechanism of action of honey produced organically. Here, we separated organic honey (OH) samples from the Brazilian Atlantic Rainforest into eight different profiles (OH-1 to OH-8) and evaluated, in vitro and in vivo, their anti-inflammatory potential. To determine cell viability, RAW 264.7 macrophages were treated with several concentrations of OH-1 up to OH-8, and anti-inflammatory activity was assessed through NF-κB activation and TNF-α levels. All types of the studied honey up to a concentration of 4% (w/v) did not interfere with macrophage viability and decreased NF-kB activation and TNF-α levels in macrophage culture in vitro. OH-7 was selected as the most promising anti-inflammatory and used in subsequent assays. Mice pretreated orally with OH-7 showed a decrease in neutrophil migration and TNF-α level. Thus, these types of Brazilian organic honey show promising anti-inflammatory potential, particularly the OH-7 variety. Brazilian organic honey may lead to the development of new products and/or be incorporated into food for use in veterinary medicine and human health as well.

motivations: There is a need to understand the anti-inflammatory effects of organic honey and its potential benefits for human health.
The chemical composition of organic honey and its mechanism of action in reducing inflammation are not well studied.
objectives: Evaluate the anti-inflammatory potential of Brazilian organic honey from the Atlantic Rainforest.
Determine the cell viability and anti-inflammatory activity of different profiles of organic honey.
methods: Separate organic honey samples into different profiles and evaluate their anti-inflammatory potential in vitro and in vivo.
Use RAW 264.7 macrophages to assess cell viability, NF-κB activation, and TNF-α levels.
Conduct in vivo assays using mice to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of the most promising honey profile.
results: Brazilian organic honey shows promising anti-inflammatory potential, particularly the OH-7 variety.
The studied honey profiles decrease NF-kB activation and TNF-α levels in macrophage culture and reduce neutrophil migration and TNF-α levels in mice.
The findings may lead to the development of new products or incorporation of Brazilian organic honey into food for veterinary medicine and human health.
llama_json.research_subject: Anti-inflammatory effects of Brazilian organic honey from the Atlantic Rainforest

motivations: Honey has been associated with several beneficial biological effects, including health improvement and control of inflammatory processes, but the mechanism of action of organically produced honey is not well-studied.
There is a need to explore the anti-inflammatory potential of organic honey from the Brazilian Atlantic Rainforest.
objectives: Separate organic honey samples from the Brazilian Atlantic Rainforest into different profiles and evaluate their anti-inflammatory potential both in vitro and in vivo.
Determine the cell viability and anti-inflammatory activity of different types of honey through NF-κB activation and TNF-α levels.
methods: Treat RAW 264.7 macrophages with several concentrations of different honey profiles and assess cell viability and anti-inflammatory activity.
Select the most promising anti-inflammatory honey profile and use it in subsequent assays.
Evaluate the effect of the selected honey profile on neutrophil migration and TNF-α level in mice.
results: All types of the studied honey up to a concentration of 4% (w/v) did not interfere with macrophage viability and decreased NF-kB activation and TNF-α levels in vitro.
Mice pretreated orally with the selected honey profile (OH-7) showed a decrease in neutrophil migration and TNF-α level.
Brazilian organic honey, particularly the OH-7 variety, shows promising anti-inflammatory potential.
openai_json.research_subject: Anti-inflammatory potential of organic honey from the Brazilian Atlantic Rainforest

motivations: While honey has been recognized for its health benefits and anti-inflammatory properties, the mechanism of action of organically produced honey remains unexplored.
There is a need to investigate the therapeutic potential of Brazilian organic honey from the Atlantic Rainforest for controlling inflammatory processes.
objectives: Evaluate the anti-inflammatory potential of different profiles of Brazilian organic honey from the Atlantic Rainforest both in vitro and in vivo.
Identify the most promising organic honey variety for anti-inflammatory applications and elucidate its mechanism of action.
methods: Separated organic honey samples into eight different profiles and tested their effects on RAW 264.7 macrophage viability and inflammatory markers.
Assessed anti-inflammatory activity by measuring NF-κB activation and TNF-α levels in macrophage cultures.
Conducted in vivo experiments using mice to evaluate neutrophil migration and TNF-α levels after oral pretreatment with selected honey.
results: All honey types up to 4% concentration maintained macrophage viability while decreasing NF-κB activation and TNF-α levels in vitro.
OH-7 variety showed the most promising anti-inflammatory effects, reducing neutrophil migration and TNF-α levels in mice.
Brazilian organic honey demonstrates potential for development into new therapeutic products for veterinary and human health applications.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Anti-inflammatory properties of Brazilian organic honey from Atlantic Rainforest
